awd_titl_txt: Evolved DNA contacts required for hexameric helicase unwinding
awd_abstract_narration:
Hexameric DNA replication helicases are structurally conserved and essential enzymes present throughout all domains of life including most viruses. They utilize a common topological strategy of encircling one strand of duplex DNA to physically separate the duplex by coupled ATP hydrolysis, which results in separated single-strand DNA templates for leading and lagging strand DNA synthesis. Earlier research in the field has focused on DNA contacts within the central channel of these helicases, while recently identified exterior contacts with the excluded DNA strand have largely remained unexplored. This project will assess the importance of external helicase contacts in controlling the speed of DNA replication through direct or indirect interactions with the excluded strand. Because a multitude of hexameric helicases across all domains of life will be compared for the nature of the interactions and the consequences of disrupting them, both in vitro and in vivo, the scientific scope and impact is expected to be broad and influential. Undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in techniques of single molecule fluorescence, advanced enzyme kinetics and precise genetic manipulation. Scientific outreach programs will encourage local elementary school students to explore the wonders of their own genome through "DNA Days" and engage students in electromagnetism by building their own working audio speakers.   

The mechanism of DNA unwinding by hexameric helicases during genome replication currently focuses solely on interactions with the encircled strand and overlooks the implication of contacts with the excluded strand. Preliminary work suggests that these external contacts could be more influential in controlling the speed of replication, coupling enzymes at the replication fork and sensing DNA damage. This project will interrogate and quantify precise chemical specificities of excluded strand interactions, and monitor mutational consequences on replisome speed, enzymatic coordination, and genomic stability, both in vitro and in vivo. The resulting data, methods, and findings will be broadly distributed within the scientific community and will provide further insights and comparisons into the precise mechanisms of action of hexameric helicases in DNA replication across all domains of life.

This project is funded jointly by the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
For this project, we have furthered our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA unwinding by hexameric DNA helicases. Helicases are conserved across all forms of life, are necessary for the separation of duplex DNA during replication, and mutated forms are implicated in a number of diseases including aging and cancer. The structural homology of hexameric helicases is quite high, however, they have evolved from at least two separate paths; one in bacteria and virus and the other in archaea and humans. Hexameric helicases are a great example of structurally convergent evolution for a common function. This common architecture would suggest that DNA unwinding mechanism are now conserved, however, we have discovered additional regulatory mechanisms that control DNA loading and unwinding and are dependent on the class of helicase.

The impact of this project on the DNA replication field should be quite substantial. The mechanism of DNA unwinding at the replication fork is still unresolved even after many biochemical and EM structural studies on the bacterial, yeast, and human systems have been solved over the past several years. Whereas most structural studies focus on discrete steps of loading or unwinding, we are making strides in understanding the complete kinetic DNA unwinding mechanisms from the perspective of both DNA strands and the structure function relationship of the enzymes in both in vitro and in vivo studies. Importantly, we developed experiments and techniques to absolutely determine the translocation orientation of the MCM helicase on DNA putting to rest a controversy in the field.  We have utilized and developed advanced interdisciplinary approaches including single molecule detection of binding, unwinding, and dynamics, presteady-state kinetics to monitor enzyme orientations on DNA, structural mass spectrometry, and in vivo biochemistry methods to solve complex problems regarding helicase function. Our goals are to measure the active unwinding mechanism from both kinetic, structural, and cellular standpoints. It is now clear that there are several conformations of the helicase and specific contacts with each of the DNA strands that together regulate the unwinding speed. By installing these biochemically characterized helicase mutants in vivo through site-specific gene editing, we can now better understand the genomic consequences to decoupling of unwinding and DNA synthesis within the replisome. More rapid DNA unwinding causes the helicase to separate from the polymerase leaving gaps in the DNA that are filled in an error prone manner cause gross chromosomal alterations and decreased cellular fitness. We have developed some unique cellular assays to biochemically characterize helicase mutants in vivo. Altogether, we have compared and contrasted mechanisms across enzyme superfamilies and subclasses to better understand mechanistic diversity across organisms. For this, we are revealing the importance and consequences of coupling DNA unwinding with DNA synthesis and merging in vitro and in vivo experiments for better insights into how structure-function mechanisms translate to genomic maintenance efficiencies.
